questions.text: Can the program or project requirements be clearly defined at this stage?
Can the program or project scope and objectives be clearly developed?
Are there only a few quality requirements to which the program or project needs to conform that do not contradict one another?
Are the program or project or program assumptions and constraints likely to remain stable?
Are stakeholder requirements unlikely to change frequently?
Are there a limited number of dependency relationships among the components of the program or project?
Does the program or project manager have the authority to apply internal or external resources to program or project activities?
Are there plans to transition processes and/or products to the customer or client?
Will the deliverable(s) of the program or project utilize only a few different technologies (e.g., electrical, mechanical, digital)?
Will the deliverable(s) of the program or project have a manageable number of components, assemblies, and interconnected parts?
Does the program or project have clearly defined boundaries with other programs or projects and initiatives that may be running in parallel?
Is there consistency between what the customer communicates and what the customer actually needs?
Are the program or project team members based within the same region?
Is it feasible to obtain accurate program or project status reporting throughout the life of the project?
Is the program or project being coordinated within a single organization?
Will the program or project be conducted in a politically and environmentally stable country?
Will the program or project team members primarily work face-to-face (rather than virtually) throughout the program or project?
Is there open communication, collaboration, and trust among the stakeholders and the program or project team?
Will the program or project have an impact on a manageable number of stakeholders from different countries, backgrounds, languages, and cultures?
Does the organization have the right people, with the necessary skills and competencies, as well as the tools, techniques, or resources to support the program or project?
Is the senior management team fully committed to the program or project?
Will the program or project be conducted over a relatively short period of time, with a manageable number of stakeholder changes?
Does the program or project have the support, commitment, and priority from the organization and functional groups?
Is funding for the program or project being obtained from a single source or sponsor?
Have the success criteria for the program or project been defined, documented, and agreed upon by stakeholders?
For a multiorganizational-sponsored program or project, are all organizations aligned regarding project management processes, tools, and techniques?
Are there a manageable number of third-party program or project relationships?
Has this type of program or project ever been undertaken by the organization?
Are the actual rate and type or propensity for change manageable?
Does the program or project have a manageable number of issues, risks, and uncertainties?
31 Are the legal or regulatory requirements to which the program or project must comply manageable?
Will suppliers be able to meet commitments to the program or project?
Is there a high degree of confidence in the estimate to complete (ETC) for the program or project?
Have realistic expectations been set around the program or project success criteria?
Will the program or project deliver to the committed deadlines?
Is the client prepared to accept and sign off on the deliverables?

Are the program or project documents and files being kept current in an accessible location for the team (e.g., plan baseline, final plan, change authorizations, payments, correspondence, or contracts)?
Have all contracts related to the program or project been free of any claims filed by suppliers or customers?
Have all parts of the program or project been free from any financial penalties?
Is an agreed framework in place for financial tracking at a work package level?
Are the program or project metrics appropriate, stable, and reported regularly?
Is there a high level of confidence that new information generated from progressive elaboration is captured appropriately in the program or project plan?
Is there a high level of confidence that the interconnected components of the program or project will perform in a predictable manner?
Is it possible to terminate, suspend, or cancel a program or project activity when there is evidence that achievement of the desired outcome is not possible?
Are team members or stakeholders able to accept the program or project data or information that may be contrary to their beliefs, assumptions, or perspectives?
Is there an effective portfolio management process within the organization to facilitate strategic alignment and enable successful delivery of programs and projects?

Does the sponsor organization or project organization conduct its business (e.g., make decisions, determine strategies, set priorities, etc.) in a manner that promotes transparency and trust among its internal and external stakeholders?
Are there a manageable number of critical paths in the program or project?
